newsitem.title: USA: SEC junks some fees, could save firms $9mln yearly.
newsitem.headline: SEC junks some fees, could save firms $9mln yearly.

text.p: The Securities and Exchange Commission on Tuesday eliminated a corporate filing fee in a move that is expected to save corporations about $9 million annually, the SEC said.
The so-called Independent Offices Approriations Act (IOAA) fees were first imposed in 1972 to help pay the cost of running the agency, the nation's top securities watchdog.
The fees range from $100 to $500 and are collected from companies filing financial reports, preliminary proxy statements, tender offers and requests for rule exemptions.
The SEC said it agreed with House of Representatives Commerce Committee Chairman, Thomas Bliley, a Virginia Republican, to do away with the fees.
The reason, it said, was that the fees collected were less than 2.0 percent of all fees it collects. But processing by the SEC staff of the IOAA fees were "disproportionately burdensome," it added.
SEC Chairman Levitt said: "As any corporate chief executive will tell you, if you are spending 50 percent of your effort collection two percent of your revenue, you need to rethink your priorities."
Bliley commended Levitt for the effort and said he was "very optimistic" that a bill deregulating the securities induutry would be enacted before Congress adjourns this year.
The bill includes a compromise Bliley worked out with the White House that would reduce the SEC's corporate registration fees by $850 million over a 10 year period.
The fees to be reduced and the IOAA fees are more than double the operating budget of the SEC, which is about $300 million.

The securities bill is currently pending in a House-Senate conference committee. Legislative aides said a number of issues still need to be worked out, including varying versions on how to effectively regulate the burgeoning investment advisory business.
